articles.title: SFA’s plan for new fifth tier of Scottish football scrapped
articles.description: Plans for a new fifth tier of Scottish football featuring top-flight B teams have been withdrawn following a fresh wave of opposition in the run-up to today’s
articles.content:
Plans for a new fifth tier of Scottish football featuring top-flight B teams have been withdrawn following a fresh wave of opposition in the run-up to today’s scheduled vote.

Cinch Premiership sides Livingston and St Mirren were among more than a dozen clubs to publicly come out against the proposals in the days leading up to the Scottish Football Association annual general meeting.

The SFA board decided to shelve the resolution less than 24 hours before the meeting and go back to the drawing board.

Clubs have now been told that resolution seven has been withdrawn in order to carry out further consultation on the best player pathway for young Scottish players.

A ten-team Conference League would have proposed up to four B teams competing

keywords.name: the Scottish Football Association annual general meeting

articles.summary: The Scottish Football Association has scrapped its plans for a new fifth tier of Scottish football featuring top-flight B teams after a wave of opposition from more than a dozen clubs. The SFA board decided to shelve the resolution less than 24 hours before the meeting and go back to the drawing board. Clubs have now been told that resolution seven has been withdrawn in order to carry out further consultation on the best player pathway for young Scottish players. A ten-team Conference League would have proposed up to four B teams competing.

articles.title: Genealogical society apologises for its own roots
articles.description: A prominent genealogical society that helps Americans trace their family histories has apologised after an investigation of its own roots revealed links to the
articles.content:
A prominent genealogical society that helps Americans trace their family histories has apologised after an investigation of its own roots revealed links to the eugenics movement and a membership that voted against integration during the early days of the civil rights movement.

The National Genealogical Society (NGS), based in Virginia, has published a report detailing “racist and discriminatory actions and decisions” that it made during the first half of its 120-year history.

The society’s apology comes five months after a similar mea culpa from the American Society of Human Genetics, which said that it had failed to “oppose harms and injustices tied to the field, including use of human genetics to feed racism, eugenics and other systemic forms of discrimination”.

articles.summary: The National Genealogical Society (NGS) has apologised after an investigation of its own roots revealed links to the eugenics movement and a membership that voted against integration during the early days of the civil rights movement. The society has published a report detailing “racist and discriminatory actions and decisions” that it made during the first half of its 120-year history. The apology comes five months after a similar mea culpa from the American Society of Human Genetics, which said that it had failed to “oppose harms and injustices tied to the field, including use of human genetics to feed racism, eugenicism and other systemic forms of discrimination”

articles.title: Leicester City confirm departure of six first-team players

articles.content:
Leicester City have confirmed the departure of six first-team players as their summer clearout begins.

Youri Tielemans, Daniel Amartey, Ryan Bertrand, Caglar Soyuncu, Ayoze Pérez and Nampalys Mendy’s contracts have not been renewed, while Tete’s loan has expired and he will return to his parent club, Shakhtar Donetsk.

Tielemans, who spent four years at Leicester, said an emotional goodbye to supporters with an Instagram post last week. “I’m bidding farewell to this incredible club,” he said. “I am forever grateful for your support.” No decision has been made on his next club but Aston Villa are among several suitors.

Leicester are in discussions with Jonny Evans over a new deal, with the captain’s contract expiring this month. Evans said after the final game of the
articles.summary: Leicester City have confirmed the departure of six first-team players, including Youri Tielemans, Daniel Amartey, Ryan Bertrand, Caglar Soyuncu, Ayoze Pérez and Nampalys Mendy. Tete's loan has expired and he will return to his parent club, Shakhtar Donetsk. No decision has been made on his next club but Aston Villa are among several suitors. articles.title: UK consumers slow spending in May as rising food costs bite
articles.description: British retail sales growth slowed to a seven-month low in May as soaring food prices prompted shoppers to rein in spending on non-essential items and dashed hopes of a boost from three public holidays, the British Retail Consortium said on Tuesday.
articles.content:
LONDON, June 6 (Reuters) - British retail sales growth slowed to a seven-month low in May as soaring food prices prompted shoppers to rein in spending on non-essential items and dashed hopes of a boost from three public holidays, the British Retail Consortium said on Tuesday.

The BRC said spending in its members' stores increased 3.9% in annual terms last month, well above the 1.1% fall a year ago. However, sales were below the 5.2% rise in April.

May's retail sales growth was the slowest since the 1.6% recorded in October 2022 when consumers cut back on purchases as inflation soared to a 41-year high of 11.1%. The BRC data is not adjusted for inflation, so May's sales growth reflects a fall in the volume of goods purchased.

Food was almost the only area where consumers spent more last month, due to higher prices as well as celebrations to mark the coronation of King Charles.

"The wild card for the retail sector remains uncontrollable food inflation, which shows little sign of coming down in the near future, and this is having a significant knock-on effect on non-essential spending," said Paul Martin, UK head of retail at accountants KPMG, who sponsor the data.

Official figures showed consumer price inflation fell less than expected in April, while food price inflation remained near a 46-year high at 19.1%, raising markets' bets that interest rates will peak at 5.5% later this year.

The Bank of England, which is expected to increase Bank Rate to 4.75% from 4.5% on June 22, has said it will keep raising interest rates if inflation looks persistent.

The BRC said retail sales in May were 3.7% higher on the year on a like-for-like basis - a measure favoured by equity analysts which adjusts for changes in retail space, down from 5.2% growth in April.

Separate figures from Barclays on Tuesday also showed high inflation and rising food prices continued to eat away at consumers' spending power.

Barclays said consumer spending on payment cards rose by 3.6% year-on-year in May, of which spending on groceries increased 8.9%, the highest growth in the category since February 2021 when it stood at 27.0%.

"Although the latest headline figures show that inflation has fallen due to lower energy prices, the prices of core services and goods remain stubbornly high and continue to constrain real household disposable income and spending," Barclays economist Silvia Ardagna said.
articles.summary: The British Retail Consortium reported that British retail sales growth slowed to a seven-month low in May due to rising food prices and low hopes of a boost from three public holidays. The BRC said spending in its members' stores increased 3.9% in annual terms last month, well above the 1.1% fall a year ago. Food was almost the only area where consumers spent more last month due to higher prices as well as celebrations to mark the coronation of King Charles. Separate figures from Barclays also showed high inflation and rising food Prices continued to eat away at consumers' spending power. The Bank of England is expected to increase Bank Rate to 4.75% from 4.5% on June 22, and will keep raising interest rates if inflation looks persistent.

articles.title: Immigration can help keep down UK inflation, says IMF deputy
articles.description: With inflation as high as it is, "there are benefits to having workers come in", the institute says.
articles.content:
Net migration (the difference between the number of people entering the country and those leaving on a long-term basis) is at a record level in the UK - at 606,000 in 2022, according to the Office for National Statistics.

"In this context, with inflation as high as it is, having workers who can fill the shortages in some of the sectors that we're seeing right now will help with bringing inflation down," Ms Gopinath, the deputy managing director of the IMF, said.

"We put that estimate out around 2018 and we haven't done an update since then for the reason that we've had the pandemic and that we've had many other shocks," she said.

"So just identifying how much is purely Brexit becomes much harder to do. But if you look at the more recent estimates by the Bank of England and others, this is in the ballpark.

"Investment has been weaker since 2016, labour market flexibility has come down and the intensity of trade of the UK with the EU has come down. So all of these factors are in line with a weakening economy."

"We now have a points-based immigration system, giving the British people full control of the country's borders, which is designed to flex to the needs of the economy to ensure we have the skills we need.

"We want businesses to invest in our domestic workforce to fill labour shortages, but where there's an acute need for staff, we have also been flexible, including putting care homes and the seafood industry on the shortage occupation list," a spokesperson said.
articles.summary: The IMF's deputy managing director, Ms Gopinath, has said that net migration is at a record level in the UK, with 606,000 people entering the country each year. This means that workers who can fill the shortages in some of the sectors that are experiencing will help keep down UK inflation, she said. The IMF has also introduced a points-based immigration system to give the British people full control of the country's borders, allowing businesses to invest in their domestic workforce and to fill labour shortages.

articles.title: CNN's Chris Licht apologizes to staff as questions grow about his future
articles.description: CNN is losing viewers and its boss has lost the trust of his staff. Warner Bros. Discovery now has to try to salvage Licht's tenure as chief executive.
articles.content:
Former television producer Chris Licht, shown here at an event in New York in 2019, faces an uncertain future at CNN.

CNN Chairman Chris Licht is trying to win back the support of his troops following a disastrous magazine piece about his first year at the network.

Licht expressed regret Monday to staffers about the Atlantic profile by journalist Tim Alberta, described by many media industry longtimers as an unusually damaging story about a prominent media executive.

The piece comes after a tumultuous period for CNN under Licht’s tenure that has been marked by cost-cutting pressures, programming missteps and declining audiences.

Executives and employees throughout CNN and its Warner Bros. Discovery were outraged by the story, and the top conversation internally is how much longer Licht can last in the job, according to several insiders who were not authorized to discuss the matter publicly.

Licht gave unfettered access for the Atlantic article, considered an unusual decision in itself when a company or network is undergoing a makeover. In the story, Licht disparaged CNN coverage under his popular predecessor Jeff Zucker while appearing to be oddly obsessed with him.

The story — “Inside the Meltdown at CNN” — also stated what many inside CNN say privately: that Licht has been an isolated leader primarily concerned with Warner Bros. Discovery Chief Executive David Zaslav’s mandate that the network be more hospitable to Republicans and address his perceived need to restore trust with viewers.

Based on his remarks he made at the network’s morning meeting, Licht recognized the damage the piece has caused internally.

“To those whose trust I’ve lost, I will fight like hell to win it back, because you deserve a leader who will be in the trenches, fighting to ensure CNN remains the world’s most trusted name in news,” Licht said.

Such a slice of humble pie coming from a chief executive is rare and a strong indication of Licht’s cloudy future at the network.

The drumbeats that Licht’s days may be numbered were heightened by last week’s announcement that Zaslav has dispatched one of his most trusted lieutenants, David Leavy, to serve as chief operating officer at CNN. He starts in the role on June 20.

The rationale for the move is that Leavy will handle business, operational and promotional activities across CNN, freeing Licht to focus on programming and editorial.

But the narrative circulating inside CNN is that Leavy will be getting working knowledge of the division so he could eventually take over in the event Licht cannot turn things around.

Leavy’s arrival is aimed at giving Warner Bros. Discovery time to figure out if Licht can be rescued, as Warner Bros. Discovery insiders believe Zaslav is loath to make another high-profile management change so soon. Warner Bros. Discovery wants to make that determination before the presidential campaign season — typically a strong period for CNN — gets into full swing.

Zaslav did issue a statement late last week after the Atlantic story, saying he still has confidence in Licht.

“CNN is a very important business for us, and, in fact, we believe that nothing we do is more important,” Zaslav said in a statement. “We aspire to be the news organization most trusted by viewers globally. We set a high bar for ourselves and while we know that it will take time to complete the important work that’s underway, we have great confidence in the progress that Chris and the team are making and share their conviction in the strategy.”

Nevertheless, Licht is now topping a growing list of issues that have plagued Zaslav since taking over as the big boss overseeing CNN, Warner Bros. film and TV studios and HBO.

The veteran executive has presided over layoffs of thousands of people.

Late last month, the company stumbled during its rebrand of the streaming service HBO Max, changing the name to Max to appeal to heartland consumers turned off by the coastal elite appeal of HBO. But the new app infuriated Hollywood talent by lumping directors, writers and producers into a single generic category called “creators.”

Despite the show of support for Licht, Leavy is acting like an executive who will be deeply involved in all aspects of the network. He has already reached out to on-air talent at the network and the agents who represent them, according to several people who have been contacted.

When Leavy talks with employees, he will likely hear about low morale under Licht’s leadership, which they have privately complained about for months, according to several insiders. Their unhappiness can be reflected in the number of unflattering stories leaked about the company, something that happened rarely when Zucker was in charge.

Leavy, 53, has no experience running a news organization but is familiar with Washington politics. Before joining Discovery in 2000, he worked as a press spokesman during the Clinton administration, including at the National Security Council, U.S. State Department and the White House.

Even before the Leavy announcement, Warner Bros. Discovery management was already concerned with CNN’s direction under Licht, who arrived in 2022 with a record as a successful TV producer thanks to his work on “Late Show With Stephen Colbert,” MSNBC’s “Morning Joe” and “CBS This Morning.” During a CNN town hall with employees in March, Zaslav conceded that mistakes had been made.

The transition from executive producer to the chief executive of a nearly 4,000-person news organization has turned out to be perilously fraught.

Licht, 51, entered the job facing a string of challenges that were not of his making, including a soft TV advertising market, the shrinking number of pay TV consumers and numerous rounds of layoffs and cost-cutting due to the parent company’s enormous debt.

But Licht baffled people inside the company by choosing to make a new morning program his first priority when the network needed to bolster its prime-time lineup after losing its top-rated personality Chris Cuomo. “CNN This Morning” is often the least-watched show of the day and two of its three co-anchors have been moved off the program, including Don Lemon, who was fired following a backlash over making sexist remarks.

Lemon was delivering the kind of liberal commentary in prime time that made Zaslav unhappy. But Licht was told that moving Lemon to the morning, where the ability to banter spontaneously is a must, was not a good solution, according to one former CNN executive who was not authorized to comment.

Lemon faced a backlash over ill-advised comments about Republican presidential candidate Nikki Haley being past her “prime.”

Warner Bros. Discovery executives were also irked that Licht said there would be no layoffs at CNN following the closing of its short-lived streaming service. Licht was forced to make more personnel cuts.

But the network’s troubles became a full-blown crisis following the May 10 town hall with former President Trump, who long ridiculed the network for being “fake news.”

The town hall format was panned internally and externally, as Trump was able to play to cheering supporters in the New Hampshire audience and deliver falsehoods at a faster rate than moderator Kaitlan Collins could fact-check.

Veteran CNN correspondent Christiane Amanpour publicly denounced the decision to give Trump such a forum.

“My management believes they did the right thing as service to the American people,” Amanpour told an audience at Columbia Journalism School on May 18. “I still respectfully disagree with allowing Donald Trump to appear in that particular format.”

Licht and the company defended the decision to feature the former president with a prime-time appearance because polls show him as the Republican frontrunner for the 2024 race for president. But Amanpour’s colleagues shared her message on social media in solidarity, an outright rebuke of Licht.

While the town hall attracted more than 3 million viewers, the audience has left CNN in droves since, with the network finishing behind the small, right-wing network Newsmax on some nights in prime time. Veterans at CNN said the Nielsen data shows that its audience is clearly angry at the network.
articles.summary: Chris Licht, former television producer, has expressed regret to staff after a damaging magazine piece about his first year at CNN caused a major uproar among executives and employees. The story suggested that Licht was an isolated leader primarily concerned with Warner Bros. and that he needed to restore trust with viewers. David Leavy, a trusted lieutenant, has been appointed as chief operating officer and is seen as a potential asset to Warner Bros.'s efforts to restore confidence in Licht. Leavy's arrival is aimed at giving Warner Bros., who is loath to make another high-profile management change so soon. Despite this, Licht is still seen as an executive involved in all aspects of the network.

articles.title: Jason Derulo: My 'most unsexy' business investment in a car wash
articles.description: The Savage Love singer says when wants to invest he looks for firms in sectors he understands.
articles.content:
Stuck for what to do, he decided to give TikTok a go. Within months, he was one of the most popular creators on the short-form video app, with more than 50 million followers.

Some artists, like UK singer PinkPantheress, used the platform to kickstart their careers and attract the interest of a record label. But for Derulo it was a way to relaunch his career in a new direction.

But TikTok may not be around for ever. Social media fashions change, and in recent months, there have been moves in the US, Europe and Canada to restrict access to TikTok, citing security threats from the Chinese-owned company. India has already banned the app.

"I would hate for it to happen but, honestly, I stay on my toes. I'm prepared for anything. If it goes away, I think there are a lot of apps out there."
articles.summary: Jason Derulo, creator of the popular short-form video app TikTok, recently decided to give it a go to relaunch his career. Within months, he was one of the most popular creators on the app, with more than 50 million followers. However, in recent months, there have been moves in the US, Europe and Canada to restrict access to the app due to security threats from the Chinese-owned company. India has already banned the app. Derulo is prepared for anything if it goes away, and believes there are a lot of apps out there.

articles.title: Northern Ireland criminal justice system 'at breaking point'
articles.description: On average, cases take twice as long to conclude in Northern Ireland compared to England and Wales.
articles.content:
The victims of crime commissioner designate Geraldine Hanna said she has spoken to victims who would not report a crime again after their experience in the justice system

Geraldine Hanna, the victims of crime commissioner designate, said "people talk about the health service being broken, I think our justice system is not far off".

It comes after a report warned that victims were being failed by long delays to cases going through court.

Victims in serious criminal cases - including murder - have told BBC News NI's Spotlight programme that delays have put their lives on hold and traumatised them further.

Speaking to Spotlight, Ms Hanna said: "Anecdotally from victims and police, I have heard of examples being given where the victim has maybe said that delay has impacted on their decision to withdraw (from a case)."

She said she has spoken to victims who told her they would not report a crime again because of their experience in the justice system.

"For me, when the people who are going through it are coming away saying they wouldn't report it again and when we see an increase in that, that for me is a sign that the system is not fit for purpose," she added.

The report said Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) evidence files of "poor quality" continued to contribute to delays and this could have "significant consequences" in terms of slowing down the progression of cases.

When inspectors looked at police practice, they found 54% of files prepared for crown court cases "did not meet, or only partially met, the file build standards".

Both organisations said the increased complexity of cases, which require investigation of phones and computers, and disruption caused by the pandemic have slowed cases down.
articles.summary: Victims of serious criminal cases in Northern Ireland have spoken out against delays caused by the justice system. Geraldine Hanna, the victims of crime commissioner designate, said she has spoken to victims who have decided not to report a crime again due to their experience in the system. A report from the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) found that 54% of files prepared for crown court cases "did not meet, or only partially met, the file build standards". Both organisations said the increased complexity of cases, which require investigation of phones and computers, and disruption caused by a pandemic have slowed cases down.

articles.title: Hard-pressed UK shoppers feel food ‘shrinkflation’
articles.description: Consumers increasingly claim that manufacturers are reducing the size of products, Barclays research finds
articles.content:
Hard-pressed consumers feel they are becoming the victims of food industry “shrinkflation” amid signs the UK’s persistent cost of living crisis is making households more alert to the need to get value for money.

With food prices up by almost 20% in the past year, the latest snapshot of consumer activity from Barclays found households were concentrating spending on essentials and increasingly concerned that manufacturers were reducing the size of products such as chocolate bars and packets of crisps.

Two-thirds of shoppers had noticed products shrinking in size while the price had remained the same or even increased. In response, 20% of consumers said they were switching from products that had been downsized by manufacturers to instead buy in bulk.

A separate survey from the British Retail Consortium (BRC) also found spending being squeezed by falling living standards, with no evidence that May’s three bank holidays had provided a boost.

Esme Harwood, a director at Barclays, said: “Consumers are still paying close attention to their everyday spending, and we are seeing growing concerns around shrinkflation in the weekly shop.

“Many are having to forgo discretionary purchases to offset rising food prices, with clothing and restaurants most impacted.”

Barclays said consumer card spending grew by 3.6% year on year in May – less than half the latest inflation rate of 8.7% and lower than the 4.3% in April. Spending on non-essential items rose just 3% due to consumers cutting back to manage household bills, while spending on groceries rose by 8.9% – the highest rate of increase in more than two years.

The BRC reported a similar pattern. The retailers’ lobby group said the value of sales was 3.9% higher in May than in the same month a year ago, but said once adjusted for inflation there had been a hefty drop in sales volumes.

Helen Dickinson, the BRC chief executive, said: “The trio of bank holidays failed to get shoppers spending as sales growth slowed to its lowest level in six months. While food sales got a boost from the coronation weekend, this was not sustained for the rest of the month.

“Meanwhile, growth in discretionary spend continued to tumble as the high cost of living squeezed households. There was cause for some optimism, however, as brighter weather at the end of the month led to a much-needed pickup in summer fashion sales, as well as gardening and DIY products.”

The latest monthly health check of the UK’s service sector said rising wages were pushing up business costs and prompting firms to raise prices.

The S&P/Chartered Institute of Procurement and Supply (Cips) purchasing managers’ survey found upward pressure on pay had not prevented strong growth for the sector last month, with the business activity index above 50 for a fourth month. Readings above 50 indicate an expanding sector.

Tim Moore, the economic indices director at S&P global market intelligence, which compiled the survey, said: “Intense wage pressures continued across the service economy, despite a moderation in employment growth. Higher salary payments more than offset lower fuel costs, which meant that overall input price inflation edged up to its strongest for three months in May.

“Average prices charged by service sector companies nonetheless increased at the second-weakest pace since August 2021 amid some reports of greater price resistance among clients.”

Fresh data from the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) showed new car registrations rose by 16.7% in May to 145,204.

While registrations remained 21% below their level in May 2019 – the last year before the start of the Covid-19 pandemic – last month’s increase marked the 10th increase in a row, the longest period of uninterrupted growth since 2015.

Mike Hawes, the SMMT chief executive, said: “After the difficult, Covid-constrained supply issues of the last few years, it’s good to see the new car market maintain its upward trend and the fact that growth is, increasingly, green growth is hugely encouraging.”
articles.summary: UK shoppers are feeling the effects of food industry “shrinkflation” due to the UK’s persistent cost of living crisis, with food prices up by almost 20% in the past year. Consumers are increasingly concerned that manufacturers are reducing the size of products such as chocolate bars and packets of crisps, while two-thirds of shoppers have noticed products shrinking in size while the price has remained the same or even increased. A separate survey from the British Retail Consortium (BRC) also found spending being squeezed by falling living standards, with no evidence that May”s three bank holidays had provided a boost. The S&P/Chartered Institute of Procurement and Supply (Cips) purchasing managers’ survey found upward pressure on pay had not prevented strong growth for the sector last month, with the business activity index above 50 for a fourth month. Fresh data from the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) showed new car registrations rose by 16.7% in May to 145,204, while registrations remained 21% below their level in May.

articles.title: Breastfed children get best GCSE exam marks
articles.description: Breastfed children are about twice as likely to go on to achieve top GCSE results, an Oxford study has found.Researchers looked at data from 4,940 pupils in Eng
articles.content:
Breastfed children are about twice as likely to go on to achieve top GCSE results, an Oxford study has found.

Researchers looked at data from 4,940 pupils in England born between 2000 and 2002.

One third of the children had never been breastfed, with the rest breastfed for different periods. One in ten were breastfed for at least 12 months.

Performance in GCSE exams, taken at the age of 16, was found to increase incrementally the longer children’s mothers had breastfed them. This is probably because nutrients in breast milk boost brain development, the study’s authors said. Breastfeeding for at least four months significantly increased the likelihood of children passing at least five GCSEs.

Only 10 per cent of the non-breastfed group achieved an A*
articles.summary: Oxford study has found that breastfed children are twice as likely to achieve top GCSE exam marks than those who had never been breastfed, with one in ten being breastfed for at least 12 months. The study looked at data from 4,940 pupils in England born between 2000 and 2002 and found that breastfeeding increased the likelihood of children passing at least five GCSEs. Only 10 per cent of the non-breastfed group achieved an A* grade, while only 10% achieved an average of A* marks. This increase in performance is thought to be due to nutrients in breast milk boosting brain development.

articles.title: Spring left us with an interesting north-south divide
articles.description: There has been an interesting pattern of weather over the UK these past several months, with the north tending to be drier than normal and the south wetter. Thi
articles.content:
There has been an interesting pattern of weather over the UK these past several months, with the north tending to be drier than normal and the south wetter. This spring brought that north-south divide into sharp relief — England had well above average rainfall, with counties such as Cambridgeshire especially wet, but parts of Scotland recorded just under two thirds of the expected rainfall.

For the past few weeks, though, dry conditions have dominated the UK, and look likely to carry on for much of this week. But by the weekend rain may edge into the southwest as a storm nudges up slightly from Spain. Eventually, rain may spread across the south while the north remains drier.

The long-range outlook for summer hints at more
articles.summary: There has been an interesting pattern of weather over the UK this spring, with the north tending to be drier than normal and the south wetter. England had well above average rainfall, but parts of Scotland recorded just under two thirds of the expected rainfall. Dry conditions have dominated the UK for the past few weeks, but by the weekend rain may edge into the southwest as a storm nudges up slightly from Spain. Eventually, rain may spread across the south while the north remains drier.

articles.title: The Times Diary: Ed aches for birthday treat
articles.description: Another year, another hurt text message from Ed Vaizey about not being in the Times birthdays column. The former arts minister and Times Radio presenter rose at dawn to scan the list eagerly and for the fourth year in a row found nothing under V. However, there are some publications where he is glad
articles.content:
Another year, another hurt text message from Ed Vaizey about not being in the Times birthdays column. The former arts minister and Times Radio presenter rose at dawn to scan the list eagerly and for the fourth year in a row found nothing under V. However, there are some publications where he is glad not to appear.

Vaizey (55 yesterday, if you hadn’t heard) has reviewed Whips, Cleo Watson’s parliamentary bonkbuster, for The House magazine and wonders how much is based on real goings-on. “It’s one book where you don’t want to be checking the index for your name,” he says. Lord Vaizey was relieved to find that none of the many sex scenes take place in the Upper House. “Those in ermine are
articles.summary: Ed Vaizey, former arts minister and Times Radio presenter, recently sent a text message saying that he was not being in the Times birthdays column. Vaizingy has reviewed Whips, Cleo Watson’s parliamentary bonkbuster, and The House magazine for the fourth year in a row. He was relieved to find that none of the many many sex scenes take place in the Upper House.

articles.title: Binance accused of a ‘web of deception’
articles.description: American regulators have sued Binance and its founder, alleging that the world’s largest cryptocurrency platform commingled customers’ funds and operated an ill
articles.content:
American regulators have sued Binance and its founder, alleging that the world’s largest cryptocurrency platform commingled customers’ funds and operated an illegal exchange in the United States under a “web of deception”.

The US Securities and Exchange Commission accuses Binance of artificially inflating trading volumes, of misleading investors over “non-existent” controls and of diverting funds to entities owned by Changpeng Zhao, its chief executive.

It has filed 13 changes against Binance and Zhao, 46, including for the operation of unregistered exchanges, broker-dealers and clearing agencies; the misrepresentation of trading controls and oversight of an American platform; and the unregistered offer and sale of securities.

Binance pledged to defend its platform “vigorously” and moved to reassure customers in the US that their assets were “safe and

entities.data: The US Securities and Exchange Commission

articles.summary: American regulators have filed 13 charges against Binance and its founder, Changpeng Zhao, for allegedly operating an illegal exchange in the US under a “web of deception” The US Securities and Exchange Commission accuses Binance of artificially inflating trading volumes, of misleading investors over “non-existent” controls and of diverting funds to entities owned by ChangpENG Zhao, its chief executive. Binance pledged to defend its platform “vigorously” and moved to reassure customers that their assets were “safe and safe.”

articles.title: Early humans prove you don’t need a big brain to feel compassion
articles.description: In the Stone Age, the Rising Star caves in South Africa were a special — possibly even sacred — place. When a member of the tribe died, they would be taken ther
articles.content:
In the Stone Age, the Rising Star caves in South Africa were a special — possibly even sacred — place. When a member of the tribe died, they would be taken there.

Arriving at the entrance, a new study claims, they were carried deep into winding narrow passageways, where abstract engravings were illuminated by the flickering light of fire. Finally, laid in the foetal position in a grave, they were carefully put to rest.

It is, in most senses, a familiar tale of our prehistory. Except, this is not our prehistory at all. These humans are not our ancestor. They were, instead, a cousin of ours — a small-brained hominin called Homo naledi that lived more than 250,000 years ago. And, say researchers, their apparent
articles.summary: A new study has revealed that early humans in the Stone Age were taken to the Rising Star caves in South Africa when a member of the tribe died. They were carried deep into winding narrow passageways and laid in a grave. This is a familiar tale of our prehistory, but it is not our ancestor. Instead, they were a small-brained hominin called Homo naledi that lived more than 250,000 years ago.

articles.title: Businessman’s £5 million boon for Labour
articles.description: Sir Keir Starmer’s election war chest will be boosted by £5 million after a businessman signalled his intention to become one of Labour’s leading donors.The su
articles.content:
Sir Keir Starmer’s election war chest will be boosted by £5 million after a businessman signalled his intention to become one of Labour’s leading donors.

The support of Gary Lubner, who recently left his role as chief executive of Belron, the parent company of Autoglass, is a big boost to the party as it tries to woo the business community.

Lubner, 64, gave £500,000 to Labour in the first quarter of the year, Electoral Commission figures will show, in addition to £217,000 in previous donations.

His previous donations have included £42,000 to pay the salary of a staff member in the office of Rachel Reeves, the shadow chancellor. Lubner grew up in South Africa, to which his Jewish grandparents fled as refugees after the pogroms
articles.summary: Businessman Gary Lubner, who recently left his role as chief executive of Belron, the parent company of Autoglass, has donated £5 million to Labour in the first quarter of the year. This is a big boost to the party as it tries to woo the business community. Previous donations have included £42,000 to pay the salary of a staff member in the office of Rachel Reeves, the shadow chancellor. Lubner grew up in South Africa and his Jewish grandparents fled as refugees after the pogroms.

articles.title: Double Helix: New musical celebrates Rosalind Franklin
articles.description: In October 1962, the Nobel prize committee named three scientists as recipients that year for cracking “a most fundamental biological problem” with their discov
articles.content:
In October 1962, the Nobel prize committee named three scientists as recipients that year for cracking “a most fundamental biological problem” with their discovery of the molecular structure of deoxyribonucleic acid, or DNA.

James Watson, Francis Crick and Maurice Wilkins shared the Nobel prize in physiology or medicine, but not Wilkins’s colleague, the late Rosalind Franklin, whose work was also crucial to the discovery.

Franklin, who died of ovarian cancer aged 37 in 1958, did not get the Nobel or the full credit for her contributions until later. Now, however, she is getting a musical.

Double Helix, which opened last week in Sag Harbor, on Long Island, before an expected transfer to New York City, tells Franklin’s story and manages, by all accounts, to
articles.summary: The Nobel Prize Committee in 1962 named three scientists as recipients for their discovery of the molecular structure of deoxyribonucleic acid, or DNA, in 1962. James Watson, Francis Crick and Maurice Wilkins shared the Nobel prize in physiology or medicine, but not the late Rosalind Franklin, whose work was also crucial to the discovery. Franklin, who died of ovarian cancer aged 37 in 1958, did not get the Nobel or the full credit for her contributions until later. Double Helix, which opened last week in Sag Harbor, on Long Island, tells Franklin’s story and manages her story to tell it.

articles.title: Texas magic is lure for Clifford Chance
articles.description: Clifford Chance has become the first London “magic circle” law firm to open in Texas, unveiling a ten-partner outpost in Houston to target the energy market. The firm — one of London’s band of four elite global practices — confirmed it had poached seven partners from rivals, including Latham & Wa
articles.content:
Clifford Chance has become the first London “magic circle” law firm to open in Texas, unveiling a ten-partner outpost in Houston to target the energy market.

The firm — one of London’s band of four elite global practices — confirmed it had poached seven partners from rivals, including Latham & Watkins, the American powerhouse. Clifford Chance also will transfer three partners to Houston from its New York and Paris offices.

The firm said in a statement that it expected its Houston operation “to grow in the coming months”. The move comes as business beyond traditional energy is reported to be booming in the Lone Star State.

Last August it emerged that 200 companies had relocated their headquarters to the Dallas-Fort Worth conurbation alone since 2010,
articles.summary: Clifford Chance, a London “magic circle” law firm, has opened a ten-partner outpost in Houston, Texas to target the energy market. The firm has poached seven partners from rivals Latham & Watkins, and will transfer three partners from its New York and Paris offices. The move comes as business beyond traditional energy is reported to be booming in the Lone Star State, with 200 companies having relocated their headquarters to the Dallas-Fort Worth conurbation alone since 2010.

articles.title: Staff named in PwC tax leak scandal
articles.description: PwC has given the names of at least 67 of its consultants, including some based in the UK, to Australian politicians investigating a tax leak scandal that thre
articles.content:
PwC has given the names of at least 67 of its consultants, including some based in the UK, to Australian politicians investigating a tax leak scandal that threatens the firm’s global reputation.

In response to questions, PwC has written to the Australian Senate giving the names of current and former staff potentially connected to the leaking of confidential government tax plans.

Among them were four former partners, in addition to 63 workers who received at least one email containing information about planned changes to tax avoidance laws in Australia. The letter, first reported by the Australian Financial Review, has not been made publicly available.

The majority of the recipients were based in Australia, but PwC consultants in Britain, as well as other countries such as
articles.summary: PwC has given the names of at least 67 of its consultants to Australian politicians investigating a tax leak scandal. The list includes four former partners, 63 workers, and one email containing information about planned changes to tax avoidance laws in Australia. The majority of the recipients were based in Australia, but PwC consultants in Britain. The letter has not been made publicly available.

articles.title: Warning over further Hinkley Point delays
articles.description: The only nuclear plant under construction in Britain is at growing risk of further delays and cost overruns, its French developer has warned.When the Hinkley Po
articles.content:
The only nuclear plant under construction in Britain is at growing risk of further delays and cost overruns, its French developer has warned.

When the Hinkley Point C plant in Somers got the go-ahead in 2016, first power was expected in late 2025. That then slipped to June 2027 at the earliest, with the potential for a further 15-month delay.

Now, however, the French state-controlled energy group has warned that “the risk of additional delays and budget overruns is increasing”. EDF, which said in February that the cost of the project could spiral to £32.7 billion, gave no further details alongside its latest alert, which was issued within a presentation to investors in recent weeks, and a spokesman for the group declined to comment.
articles.summary: French state-controlled energy group EDF has warned that the Hinkley Point C nuclear plant in Somers, the only nuclear plant under construction in Britain, is at risk of further delays and cost overruns. The cost of the project could spiral to £32.7 billion, and EDF gave no further details alongside its latest alert.

articles.title: University ‘silences student criticism’ in assessment boycott row
articles.description: Students have accused the University of Edinburgh of attempting to silence them after they derided a senior member of staff over his stance on a marking and assessment boycott.
articles.content:
Students have accused the University of Edinburgh of attempting to silence them after they derided a senior member of staff over his stance on an acrimonious campus dispute.

Students were sent a link to a video where Professor Colm Harmon, a vice-principal, spoke about the continuing marking and assessment boycott.

But the university then deleted critical comments before disabling the feature entirely after undergraduates went online to challenge his remarks.

Lecturers have embarked on an assessment boycott as part of the nationwide dispute over pay and working conditions.

In an attempt to counter the industrial action, the university proposed a “robust” emergency response which raised fears that students could be given a binary pass or fail for submitted work.
articles.summary: Students have accused the University of Edinburgh of attempting to silence them after they derided a senior member of staff over his stance on an acrimonious campus dispute. The university then deleted critical comments before disabling the feature entirely after undergraduates went online to challenge his remarks. Students have embarked on an assessment boycott as part of the nationwide dispute over pay and working conditions, and the university proposed a “robust” emergency response which raised fears that students could be given a binary pass or fail for submitted work.

articles.title: Vicky McClure: My Grandad’s War review — a veteran’s memories of the day ‘hell let loose’
articles.description: Vicky McClure: My Grandad’s Warrecounted how Ralph took part in the D-Day landings, arriving at Sword Beach, near the town of Ouistreham, into live horror
articles.content:
When it comes to elderly war veterans, I always say that what gets me in the throat as much as the heroism is their modesty. In an age when weeping reality TV stars talk of having been “to hell and back” because they got dropped from a shampoo ad, the people who really have visited hell offer such understated comments as “things got a bit hairy” and “it wasn’t pleasant”. Ralph McClure, the 97-year-old grandfather of the actress Vicky McClure, was one such quiet hero.

Vicky McClure: My Grandad’s War recounted how Ralph took part in the D-Day landings, arriving at Sword Beach, near the town of Ouistreham, into live horror. His granddaughter
articles.summary: Vicky McClure, the granddaughter of actress Vicky and her late husband, has reviewed the book My Grandad's War, which chronicles the day Ralph McClure took part in the D-Day landings of World War II and was one of the quietest moments of his life. The book also discusses how Ralph McClures was a quiet hero who made many understated comments about the experience of hell, such as “things got a bit hairy” and “it wasn't pleasant” during the landing of D-day landings.

articles.title: He pioneered low-carbon building 20 years ago. Now the world is catching up
articles.description: When the architect Bill Dunster completed Britain’s first urban low-carbon housing project in 2002, he believed it would be the first of many. After all, with
articles.content:
When the architect Bill Dunster completed Britain’s first urban low-carbon housing project in 2002, he believed it would be the first of many. After all, with warnings of climate disaster having steadily grown and with buildings generating 39 per cent of global carbon emissions, it would have been reasonable to expect a revolution in architecture.

Dunster’s lugubrious expression tells you all you need to know about actual progress in the past 20 years. The original vision for his BedZED scheme in the south London suburb of Wallington was to build high-density living and work spaces with energy-saving features and land for agriculture, while also giving residents a roof garden and generating most of the energy they needed on site.

The £14.75 million scheme, on an

keywords.name: Britain’s first urban low-carbon housing project

articles.summary: Bill Dunster, the architect of Britain's first urban low-carbon housing project in 2002, has led to a revolution in architecture due to the growing threat of climate disaster. His BedZED scheme in Wallington, London, was designed to provide high-density living and work spaces with energy-saving features and land for agriculture, while also giving residents a roof garden and generating most of the energy they needed on site. The £14.75 million scheme was part of an £14 million scheme, on an energy-efficient scheme that generated 39 per cent of global carbon emissions.

articles.title: ‘I live in a zoo with gorillas for neighbours’
articles.description: Brandon Ballard, 34, never imagined having a residence in Central London. Then he landed his dream job working at London Zoo
articles.content:
I grew up in a village near Preston, Lancashire, with my mother and brother. Now I’m a keeper at London Zoo and live in the keepers’ lodge on the zoo grounds [says Brandon Ballard, 34].

I never imagined I’d be living in central London, let alone living in one of the most iconic conservation zoos in the world, surrounded by some of the world’s most incredible and threatened species. I’m reminded of what an interesting place it is to live in when I have friends visit. They can’t get over the fact my next-door neighbours are a troop of western lowland gorillas.

We had horses, sheep and goats at home when I was young, but when I visited a local zoo I was enthralled by
articles.summary: Brandon Ballard, a keeper at London Zoo, grew up in a village near Preston, Lancashire with his mother and brother and now lives in the keepers’ lodge on the zoo grounds. He was enthralled by a troop of western lowland gorillas when he visited a local zoo when he was young, and was reminded of what an interesting place it is to live in when friends visit.

articles.title: Criticising the Bank for its diversity misses the point to a ludicrous degree
articles.description: In the United States, “critical race theory” has become a catch-all slur wielded by right-wing commentators and Republicans as the source of many of America’s
articles.content:
In the United States, “critical race theory” has become a catch-all slur wielded by right-wing commentators and Republicans as the source of many of America’s ills. Internet memes poke fun at how the academic discipline is apparently responsible for US school shootings, social unrest and even the country’s hasty withdrawal from Afghanistan in 2021, according to Mike Pompeo, the former secretary of state.

The populist variant of this moral panic is known as “wokeism” and has long since made its way across the Atlantic. The targets are diffuse, but the “war on woke” generally rails against the degradation of institutions and wider society from “leftist” calls for racial and gender diversity, climate change awareness and LGBTI rights.

These culture wars also have begun to engulf
articles.summary: In the United States, “critical race theory” has become a catch-all slur wielded by right-wing commentators and Republicans as the source of many of America’s ills. Internet memes poke fun at how the academic discipline is apparently responsible for US school shootings, social unrest and even the country's withdrawal from Afghanistan in 2021. The populist variant of this moral panic is known as “wokeism” and has long since made its way across the Atlantic. It rails against the degradation of institutions and wider society from “leftist” calls for racial and gender diversity, climate change awareness and LGBTI rights. Culture wars have also begun to engulf culture wars, with culture wars also beginning to engulf these culture wars.

articles.title: Allan Saint-Maximin casts doubt over Newcastle United future
articles.description: Allan Saint-Maximin has cast doubt over his future at Newcastle United after posting an emotional statement on social media.The French winger, whose contract a
articles.content:
Allan Saint-Maximin has cast doubt over his future at Newcastle United after posting an emotional statement on social media.

The French winger, whose contract at St James’ Park runs until 2026, started only 12 times in the Premier League this season in a campaign beset with injury problems.

In an Instagram post on Monday evening, the 26-year-old told Newcastle supporters that his career was at a “turning point”.

“When I joined @NUFC in 2019, nobody understood my choice. I always believed in this club, as soon as I step on to the pitch, the fans directly adopted me,” he wrote in the caption to a video of some of his highlights this season.

“Since then there has been highs and lows, when we were in
articles.summary: Allan Saint-Maximin has cast doubt over his future at Newcastle United after posting an emotional statement on social media. The French winger, whose contract at St James’ Park runs until 2026, started only 12 times in the Premier League this season in a campaign beset with injury problems. He told Newcastle supporters that his career was at a “turning point” when he joined the club in 2019.

articles.title: Grammar school parents sign petition to ban mobile phones
articles.description: Parents at a large secondary school are petitioning to have their children’s mobile phones banned during the day after reports of widespread behavioural issues.
articles.content:
Parents at a large secondary school are petitioning to have their children’s mobile phones banned during the day after reports of widespread behavioural issues.

In an open letter to the teaching staff at Dunbar Grammar, they highlight numerous incidents that they believe stem from abuse of mobiles.

Reports include “inappropriate filming of staff without their consent”, “videoing of arranged fights” and “fear of students being filmed . . . in the changing room”.

The letter raises concerns that phone use in school has caused “loss of learning”, “increased incidents of bullying and cyberbullying” and “lower attainment levels”.

More than 250 parents have signed in support of limiting phone use for under-16s.

They insist the current policy is not being successfully enforced and parents have urged
articles.summary: Parents at Dunbar Grammar, a large secondary school, are petitioning to have their children's mobile phones banned during the day after reports of widespread behavioural issues. The open letter to the teaching staff highlights numerous incidents that they believe stem from abuse of mobiles, including “inappropriate filming of staff without their consent”, “videoing of arranged fights” and “fear of students being filmed. in the changing room” More than 250 parents have signed in support of limiting phone use for under-16s.

articles.title: Turkish bid is delight for Asos price
articles.description: News that Asos had received a £1 billion takeover approach drove a much-needed revival in the online fashion retailer’s share price. The business was approached
articles.content:
News that Asos had received a £1 billion takeover approach drove a much-needed revival in the online fashion retailer’s share price.

The business was approached in December by Trendyol, a Turkish online retailer backed by Alibaba, the Chinese ecommerce and technology group, The Sunday Times reported.

A deal would have valued Asos at between £10 and £12 a share, which in turn yesterday drove an increase in the stock by as much as 14.5 per cent before the shares closed up 24¾p, or 7.1 per cent, at 375¼p. Two years ago the shares were changing hands for almost £52.

Asos started out in 2000 selling clothes worn by celebrities and rapidly expanded. However, in recent years its shares have tumbled as sales languished and costs

keywords.name: the online fashion retailer’s share price

articles.summary: Asos has received a £1 billion takeover approach from Trendyol, a Turkish online retailer backed by Alibaba, the Chinese ecommerce and technology group, which would have valued the online fashion retailer at between £10 and £12 a share. The news drove an increase in the stock by as much as 14.5 per cent before the shares closed up 24¾p, or 7.1 per cent, at 375¼p. Two years ago the shares were changing hands for almost £52.

articles.title: Sunak seeks tariffs deal with Biden to protect car industry
articles.description: Rishi Sunak and President Biden will announce plans this week for more economic co-operation between Britain and America during the prime minister’s fi
articles.content:
Rishi Sunak and President Biden will announce plans this week for more economic co-operation between Britain and America during the prime minister’s first visit to the White House.

Sunak is due to travel to Washington today and will hold talks with Biden and meet business leaders on the two-day trip. Whitehall sources said that the talks were likely to result in a pledge to work towards economic partnership across a range of areas.

In particular, Biden is expected to offer fresh trade concessions to help the UK car industry, which is under threat from US green subsidies for domestic manufacturers.

This is likely to take the form of a new critical minerals agreement, which would allow UK companies that export electric vehicles to the
articles.summary: Rishi Sunak and President Biden will announce plans this week for more economic co-operation between Britain and America during the prime minister's first visit to the White House. Sunak is due to hold talks with Biden and meet business leaders on the two-day trip, which are likely to result in a pledge to work towards economic partnership across a range of areas. In particular, Biden is expected to offer fresh trade concessions to help the UK car industry, which is under threat from US green subsidies for domestic manufacturers. This is likely to take the form of a new critical minerals agreement, which would allow UK companies that export electric vehicles to the US.

articles.title: The hippy Spanish surf town that’s going upmarket
articles.description: The surfy town on the southern tip of Spain goes upmarket with a cool new house that feels like wild paradise to Bridget Harrison
articles.content:
Outdoorsy as I am, I also know my limits and so I decided a while ago to leave learning to kitesurf to my next life. Still, on arrival at Playa de Valdevaqueros in Tarifa, known as the kitesurfing capital of Europe, I am suddenly quite tempted to give it a go. It could be the sight of the glorious turquoise sea lapping a beautiful three-mile strip of white sand or the buff middle-aged guys hosing down their surfboards under a cloudless sky, but this is a scene I could embrace.

The dream ends when Mirco Bertarelli, head instructor at the Ion Club kitesurf school, tells me it will take ten hours of lessons to get to grips with this high-octane spot. And also, there is
articles.summary: Playa de Valdevaqueros, a hippy Spanish surf town known as the kitesurfing capital of Europe, is becoming increasingly popular with surfers and middle-aged surfers. Mirco Bertarelli, head instructor at the Ion Club kitesursurf school, tells me it will take ten hours of lessons to get to grips with this high-octane spot. There is also a three-mile strip of white sand and a beautiful three-minute stretch of surf.

articles.title: New museum celebrates the mastermind of Dunkirk and D-Day
articles.description: Admiral Bertram Ramsay, who commanded Operation Dynamo, which led to the rescue of more than 338,000 Allied soldiers from Dunkirk in 1940, is commemorated in a new museum.
articles.content:
He masterminded the Dunkirk evacuation and helped to organise the D-Day landings, and now the wily naval tactician who changed the course of the Second World War is being honoured with a museum dedicated to him.

Admiral Bertram Ramsay commanded Operation Dynamo, which led to the rescue of more than 338,000 Allied soldiers from Dunkirk in 1940.

Four years later he was involved in planning the Normandy landings, the largest seaborne invasion in history, which began the liberation of Europe.

Ramsay’s contribution to world history is now recognised at a visitor centre created by his grandson at Bughtrig House, near Coldstream in the Scottish Borders, his former home.

The opening of the attraction coincides with the 83rd anniversary of the Dunkirk evacuation and the 79th
articles.summary: A new museum in the Scottish Borders has been dedicated to the mastermind of the Dunkirk and D-Day landings. Admiral Bertram Ramsay commanded Operation Dynamo, which led to the rescue of more than 338,000 Allied soldiers from Dunkirk in 1940. Four years later he was involved in planning the Normandy landings, the largest seaborne invasion in history, which began the liberation of Europe. His contribution to world history is now recognised at the Bughtrig House visitor centre created by his grandson. The opening of the attraction coincides with the 83rd anniversary of the evacuation and the 79th anniversary.

articles.title: Sushi chef awarded £7,000 after fight with business partner
articles.description: A sushi chef was involved in a violent altercation with a colleague over the raw fish counter at a Waitrose store after complaining about receiving late-night W
articles.content:
A sushi chef was involved in a violent altercation with a colleague over the raw fish counter at a Waitrose store after complaining about receiving late-night WhatsApp messages. Hemanta Mainali has now been awarded more than £7,000 in a legal dispute involving his sushi bar co-worker.

An employment tribunal heard that Mainali was furious after being woken in the early hours of a Saturday morning by a message from Sumin Lohani about the work rota.

Mainali told the hearing that it was “very wrong” for his colleague to bother him at that time of night — and he acknowledged that he replied to the message by telling Lohani: “Go f*** yourself.”

The sushi chef claimed that the early morning message was not part of a

entities.data: the early hours of a Saturday

articles.summary: Hanta Mainali, a sushi chef at a Waitrose store, was involved in a violent altercation with a colleague after complaining about receiving late-night WhatsApp messages. Mainali was woken in the early hours of a Saturday morning by a message from Sumin Lohani about the work rota. He replied to the message by telling him to “Go f*** yourself” and claimed that the early morning message was not part of a work rot. He was awarded more than £7,000 in a legal dispute involving his sushi bar co-worker.

articles.title: This Is the Kit: the band who served me pop and pasties in Penzance
articles.description: Back in 1929 a practical but artistic sort called Rowena Cade had a dream of carving an amphitheatre into her cliffside garden near Penzance, Cornwall. Using ha
articles.content: Back in 1929 a practical but artistic sort called Rowena Cade had a dream of carving an amphitheatre into her cliffside garden near Penzance, Cornwall. Using hand tools, stone cutters and the odd stick of dynamite, Cade and a few volunteers built the Minack Theatre and in 1932 staged The Tempest with the raging sea as a suitable backdrop and a few car lights illuminating the stage. Wade worked on the Minack for the rest of her life, lugging up sand and rocks from the beach by wheelbarrow and etching neoclassical designs into wet concrete with a screwdriver. Generations of Cornish locals and holidaymakers have been braving sea sprays and piles-inducing stone seats to experience the outdoor theatrical magic ever since. Now, on a mercifully
articles.summary: This Is the Kit is a look back on the band that served me pop and pasties in Penzance, Cornwall. Rowena Cade, who started carving an amphitheatre into her cliffside garden in 1929, built the Minack Theatre and staged The Tempest with the raging sea as a backdrop. She also worked on the minack for the rest of her life, lugging up sand and rocks from the beach by wheelbarrow and etching neoclassical designs into wet concrete with a screwdriver. Generations of Cornish locals and holidaymakers have been braving sea sprays and piles-inducing stone seats to experience outdoor theatrical magic ever since. This Is The Kit looks back at the band's early days and looks back on their early days.

articles.title: CBI looks on the bright side of life
articles.description: Maybe this is where it all goes a bit Life of Brian. “Are you the Judean People’s Front?” “F*** off! . . . We’re the People’s Front of Judea!” Thanks to the imploding CBI, a fresh fight has ensued — not over what issues business puts in front of government but over which of the various lobby groups
articles.content:
Maybe this is where it all goes a bit Life of Brian. “Are you the Judean People’s Front?” “F*** off! . . . We’re the People’s Front of Judea!”

Thanks to the imploding CBI, a fresh fight has ensued — not over what issues business puts in front of government but over which of the various lobby groups can best represent its interests. The most explicit play yet? A “splitter” move from the British Chambers of Commerce. It’s launched a “business council” to help to turn its regional clout into a “new national offer”. And all on the eve of today’s life-or-death vote on the CBI’s future.

The timing is unmissable, with plenty to like about it, too: a red-toothed grab for market share,
articles.summary: The CBI has been under fire for not representing its interests in the government, with a new “business council” and a “splitter” move from the British Chambers of Commerce. The CBI is also trying to turn its regional clout into a national offer, and the upcoming life-or-death vote on the CBI's future is uncertain. The timing of the vote is unmissable, with plenty to like about it, too, and a red-toothed grab for market share.

articles.title: Newcastle owners PIF take over Saudi Arabia’s four biggest clubs
articles.description: Saudi Arabia’s four leading clubs have been taken over by the same sovereign wealth fund that owns Newcastle United as part of a drive to make the Gulf state a
articles.content:
Saudi Arabia’s four leading clubs have been taken over by the same sovereign wealth fund that owns Newcastle United as part of a drive to make the Gulf state a leading force in football.

The Public Investment Fund has taken a 75 per cent stake in Al Nassr, where Cristiano Ronaldo plays, as well as the Asian Champions League finalists Al Hilal, who have made an offer to Lionel Messi, plus Al Ittihad and Al Ahli.

Al Ittihad are reported to have offered deals to the France internationals Karim Benzema, who has announced that he is leaving Real Madrid, and Chelsea’s N’Golo Kanté.

PIF also owns an 80 per cent share of Newcastle, but sources said there was no intention to develop a multi-club model.
articles.summary: Saudi Arabia's four leading clubs have been taken over by the same sovereign wealth fund that owns Newcastle United. The Public Investment Fund has taken a 75 per cent stake in Al Nassr, Al Hilal, Al Ittihad and Al Ahli, as well as an offer to Lionel Messi. PIF also owns an 80 per cent share of Newcastle, but sources said there was no intention to develop a multi-club model.

articles.title: ‘Action needed’ for UK to survive global tech race
articles.description: Britain is in danger of losing its position as a global leader in technology because of the government’s failure to deliver a long-term strategy for the se
articles.content:
Britain is in danger of losing its position as a global leader in technology because of the government’s failure to deliver a long-term strategy for the sector, an influential business group has claimed.

In a scathing report, techUK accused policymakers of relying on clichés and hype, such as “unicorn kingdom” and “science and technology superpower”, of having a “habit of patting themselves on the back” and setting out grand strategic plans that are not delivered.

It claims that, with changes, the technology sector could add £200 billion to the economy every year by the middle of the decade. At present, it contributes £150 billion as one of the nation’s most “valuable economic assets”. Antony Walker, deputy chief executive of the trade association, said that if
articles.summary: TechUK has warned that the UK is in danger of losing its position as a global leader in technology due to the government's failure to deliver a long-term strategy for the sector. The report claims that the technology sector could add £200 billion to the economy every year by the middle of the decade and contribute £150 billion as one of the nation's most “valuable economic assets” at present. Antony Walker, deputy chief executive of the trade association, said that if changes were made, the sector could be added to the UK economy.

articles.title: CBI members vote on reforms today
articles.description: The director-general and the president of the CBI will make a last-ditch attempt today to sway members when they make addresses before a crunch vote on whethe
articles.content:
The director-general and the president of the CBI will make a last-ditch attempt today to sway members when they make addresses before a crunch vote on whether the business lobby group should survive.

At an extraordinary general meeting of the CBI’s members at its head office in the City of London, Rain Newton-Smith, the new director-general, is expected to say she is “confident and determined this will be a turning point for us” and that the vote represents the “start of a new chapter for a renewed CBI”.

She will add: “This is a difficult but important journey . . . I am resolutely committed to leading that change and restoring the CBI to health.”

Members will vote on the future of the CBI and
articles.summary: The CBI's new director-general, Rain Newton-Smith, is expected to make a last-ditch attempt today to sway members when they make addresses before a crunch vote on whether the business lobby group should survive. She is determined to lead the CBI to health and is committed to leading the change.

articles.title: DJ Paul Oakenfold accused of sexual harassment by former PA
articles.description: Paul Oakenfold, the electronic music producer and DJ, has been accused of sexual harassment by his former personal assistant, claims that he has categorically
articles.content:
Paul Oakenfold, the electronic music producer and DJ, has been accused of sexual harassment by his former personal assistant, claims that he has categorically denied.

Oakenfold, who has worked with Cher, U2 and Madonna, has been accused of exposing himself and carrying out a sex act in front of the staff member on several occasions, including four times in one day.

The claim, filed on Friday in Los Angeles by a 24-year-old woman identified only as Jane Roe, states that Oakenfold, 59, masturbated in front of her on the first day she worked for him in October 2022. On four occasions, on different dates, Oakenfold sexually harassed the claimant when he “was aware the plaintiff could not escape”, according to the claim. This allegedly included
articles.summary: Paul Oakenfold, the electronic music producer and DJ, has been accused of sexual harassment by his former personal assistant, Jane Roe, a 24-year-old woman identified only as Jane Roe. The claim alleges that Oaken Fold exposed himself and carried out a sex act in front of the staff member on several occasions, including four times in one day. On four occasions, on different dates, on various dates, according to the claim. Oaken fold has categorically denied the claims.

articles.title: Fleet car demand puts sales in fast lane
articles.description: Registrations of new cars have risen for a tenth month in a row, giving the market its best run of consecutive growth in eight years.Last month 145,000 new cars
articles.content:
Registrations of new cars have risen for a tenth month in a row, giving the market its best run of consecutive growth in eight years.

Last month 145,000 new cars were registered in the UK, up 16.7 per cent on May last year, while sales in the first five months rose to 772,000, up from 661,000 in the same period in 2022, an increase of 16.8 per cent.

Almost all the growth was in registrations to organisations with a fleet of 25 or more cars, a part of the market that at present accounts for more than half of sales. Growth in the company car fleet in the year to date is at more than 38 per cent, with businesses particularly active in buying electrified
articles.summary: Registrations of new cars have risen for a tenth month in a row, giving the market its best run of consecutive growth in eight years. Last month 145,000 new cars were registered in the UK, up 16.7%, while sales in the first five months rose to 772,000, up from 661,000 in the same period in 2022. Almost all the growth was in registrations to organisations with a fleet of 25 or more cars, a part of the market that at present accounts for more than half of sales. Growth in the company car fleet in the year to date is at more than 38%.

articles.title: Fifty Years of Tom Wood: Liverpool through a photographer’s lens
articles.description: Tom Wood became known around Liverpool as the “Photie Man” as he documented life in the city from the 1970s to the present day.The first major UK retrospective
articles.content:
Tom Wood became known around Liverpool as the “Photie Man” as he documented life in the city from the 1970s to the present day.

The first major UK retrospective of his work, at the Walker Art Gallery in Liverpool, showcases 50 years of his photography, which gives an insight into everyday life and culture in Merseyside and around the UK.

Wood said: “The energy of Liverpool and its people has informed all this work — it was everywhere I went, everywhere I looked. All I was doing was tapping into that. It has been a real labour of love.”

For further details and to book tickets, visit here.
articles.summary: Tom Wood, a photographer who documented life in Liverpool from the 1970s to the present day, is featured in a first major UK retrospective at the Walker Art Gallery in Liverpool. The retrospective gives an insight into everyday life and culture in Merseyside and around the UK. Wood said that the energy of Liverpool and its people informed his work, and that it has been a real labour of love.

articles.title: Dear Julia: my niece has severed ties with her mother
articles.description: The psychotherapist addresses your dilemmas
articles.content:
Q Last year my niece decided to sever links with her mother. This has been deeply upsetting to my sister and impacts the rest of the family. I can understand some of the things that may have precipitated such an action, yet is it really best to become estranged rather than try to work things through? My instinct is to try to build bridges, or should acceptance be the correct response?

A It has a huge impact on every member of the family, including the wider family. It can be experienced as a grief, often called ambiguous loss, because it feels like a death and yet the person is still alive. Estrangement is complex and painful for both the person that initiated it and the
articles.summary: Julia, a niece of Julia, has decided to sever ties with her mother, mother-of-two, and has decided not to pursue any further ties with the family. This has been deeply upsetting to her sister and impacts the rest of the family, and Julia's instinct is to try to build bridges or accept acceptance is the correct response. Estrangement is complex and painful for both the person initiated it and the person that initiated it, and it can be experienced as a grief.

articles.title: Ephemeral in Edinburgh: Chanel unveils latest pop-up
articles.description: Chanel is about to unveil the brand’s first ephemeral boutique in Edinburgh after similar pop-ups appeared in New York, Bangkok and London.
articles.content:
Chanel is about to unveil the brand’s first ephemeral boutique in Scotland after similar pop-ups appeared in New York, Bangkok and London.

The new store will open its doors on Thursday in Edinburgh and will offer ready-to-wear collections, leather goods, shoes and accessories on the city’s exclusive Charlotte Square.

Chanel’s luxury products will be displayed in a 250-year-old three-storey townhouse, with views of Edinburgh Castle and Fife.

As usual, the company is remaining tight-lipped about the opening but the new location is an A-listed house with more than 5,000 square feet of floor space and a private garden.

The building is located just yards from Bute House, the first minister’s official residence, and shares the square with investment banks, legal firms and the People’s Postcode
articles.summary: Chanel is set to unveil its first ephemeral boutique in Scotland on Thursday, offering ready-to-wear collections, leather goods, shoes and accessories on the city's exclusive Charlotte Square. The store will be located in a 250-year-old three-storey townhouse with views of Edinburgh Castle and Fife. The new location is an A-listed house with more than 5,000 square feet of floor space and a private garden. The square is located just yards from Bute House and shares the square with investment banks, legal firms and the People’s Postcode.

articles.title: Failure to remove contamination caused by oil spill not a continuing private nuisance
articles.description: Supreme CourtPublished on June 6, 2023Jalla and another v Shell International Trading and Shipping Co Ltd and anotherBefore Lord Reed, Lord Briggs, Lord Kitchin
articles.content:
Supreme Court

Published on June 6, 2023

Jalla and another v Shell International Trading and Shipping Co Ltd and another

Before Lord Reed, Lord Briggs, Lord Kitchin, Lord Sales and Lord Burrows [2023] UKSC 16

Judgment May 10, 2023

A major oil spill that was alleged to have caused oil to be present on the claimants’ land that had not been removed or cleaned up, was not a continuing nuisance but a one-off event so that the limitation period for bringing a claim in the tort of private nuisance against the alleged tortfeasor ran from the day of the actual oil spill.

The Supreme Court so held in dismissing the appeal of the claimants, Harrison Jalla and Abel Chujor, from the decision of the Court

entities.data: Shell International Trading and Shipping Co Ltd

articles.summary: The Supreme Court has dismissed the appeal of Harrison Jalla and Abel Chujor of a major oil spill that was alleged to have caused oil to be present on the claimants’ land that had not been removed or cleaned up. The Court ruled that the limitation period for bringing a claim in the tort of private nuisance against the alleged tortfeasor ran from the day of the actual oil spill.

articles.title: Ofgem urged to ensure ‘fair hearing’ for firms facing shutdown
articles.description: The energy regulator has been urged by ministers to do more to protect small businesses from suppliers seeking to shut down companies to reclaim debts.Kevin Hol
articles.content:
